p: Technological advances in molecular virology and genetics, as well as the expanded use of mathematical models in epidemiology and disease ecology have dramatically changed our ability to manage both conservation and health. Finally, it is only with this type of interdisciplinary approach that considers free-ranging wildlife, domestic animals and humans as inextricable components of a single disease system, that progress can be made that will satisfy both conservation and public health needs. This is the essence of conservation medicine [ 117] and indeed we believe a “One Health” approach to infectious disease is necessarily the way forward.
